<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a power supply. The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 137]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 152, 787, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 418, 532, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 144, 469]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 450, 692, 469]]<|/det|> Connect the crocodile clip near end \(\mathbf{X}\) of the resistance wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 482, 282, 499]]<|/det|> * Switch on. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 512, 920, 545]]<|/det|> Adjust the position of the crocodile clip until the potential difference \(V\) across terminals \(\mathbf{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\) is 2.0V. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 559, 771, 577]]<|/det|> * Record, in Table 1.1, the value of the current \(I\) shown on the ammeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 590, 861, 608]]<|/det|> * Move the crocodile clip and record values of \(I\) for \(V = 1.8 \text{V}, 1.6 \text{V}, 1.4 \text{V}\) and \(1.2 \text{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 621, 282, 637]]<|/det|> * Switch off. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 650, 539, 669]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 677, 680, 863]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 732, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the density of water by two methods.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 203, 121]]<|/det|>
# Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 653, 153]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 2.1 and 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 798, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 85, 828, 103]]<|/det|>
You will determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 776, 135]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 435, 150]]<|/det|>
You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[102, 165, 875, 897]]<|/det|>

<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

0625/53/M/J/17

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Place the block approximately in the centre of the ray-trace sheet. Carefully draw round the block and label the corners ABCD, as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 180, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 118, 552, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 150, 175, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 149, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a point \(\mathbf{L}\), \(1\mathrm{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Label the other end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 176, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 809, 215]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FL}\), \(8\mathrm{cm}\) long and at an angle \(\theta = 30^{\circ}\), as indicated by Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 243, 148, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 243, 655, 262]]<|/det|>
Replace the block in exactly the same position as in **(a)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 274, 175, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 273, 902, 292]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{FL}\), a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 175, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 304, 465, 323]]<|/det|>

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 336, 920, 386]]<|/det|>

Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), a suitable distance apart, so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 397, 175, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 428, 175, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 475, 757, 494]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 505, 725, 524]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 536, 821, 555]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through \(\mathbf{G}\), at \(90^{\circ}\) to \(\mathbf{CD}\). Extend this line until it crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 567, 737, 586]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 599, 500, 617]]<|/det|>
Extend line \(\mathbf{FL}\) until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 630, 670, 648]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 661, 556, 679]]<|/det|>
Join points \(\mathbf{L}\) and \(\mathbf{G}\) with a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 677, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 707, 180, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 707, 500, 726]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 738, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 769, 500, 787]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 800, 920, 817]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 845, 801, 866]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 655, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 549, 121]]<|/det|>
Replace the two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line FL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 178, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 839, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how increasing the number of layers of insulation affects the rate of cooling of hot water in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 522, 135]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 465, 166]]<|/det|>
Write a plan for the experiment, including:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 182, 341, 198]]<|/det|>
· the apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 214, 366, 229]]<|/det|>
· what you would measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 796, 260]]<|/det|>
· the variables you would keep the same to ensure the comparison is a fair test

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 512, 291]]<|/det|>
· instructions for carrying out the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 452, 321]]<|/det|>
· how you would present your results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 337, 620, 352]]<|/det|>
· how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 576, 383]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
